b2bpl.graph
Class AbstractFlowGraph<V extends AbstractVertex<V,E>,E extends AbstractEdge<V,E>>

java.lang.Object
  b2bpl.graph.AbstractFlowGraph<V,E>
Type Parameters:
V - A type parameter representing the concrete vertex to be used as a basic block in the control flow graph.
E - A type parameter representing the concrete edge to be used in the control flow graph.
Direct Known Subclasses:
ControlFlowGraph, ControlFlowGraph
public abstract class AbstractFlowGraph<V extends AbstractVertex<V,E>,E extends AbstractEdge<V,E>>
extends java.lang.Object

Provides a simple implementation of a control flow graph.

The vertices and edges in the control flow graph are represented by the AbstractVertex and AbstractEdge classes, respectively. In addition to providing a simple flow graph datastructure, this class also implements algorithms for detecting loops and for determining some structural properties of the flow graph such as whether it is reducible or not.

Author:
Ovidio Mallo
See Also:
AbstractVertex, AbstractEdge

Method Detail

newBlock

protected abstract V newBlock()
Special method used to delegate the creation of a new block of the flow graph to a concrete subclass. Such a method is necessary since Java provides no runtime support for generics, meaning that we cannot directly instantiate an object whose type is a type parameter.

Returns:
The newly created block of the flow graph.

analyze

public void analyze()
Analyzes this flow graph by marking every back edge as such and by checking whether the graph is reducible or not. Once this method has terminated, those properties can be quieried reliably on the corresponding edges and on this graph, respectively.

See Also:
AbstractEdge.isBackEdge(), isReducible()

markBackEdges

private void markBackEdges()
Computes all the back edges in this flow graph and marks them as such. This requires a dominator analysis to be performed.

For the dominator analysis, a simple iterative algorithm (as described in the "Dragon Book") is employed which works as follows:

  • The dominator set of the synthetic entry block of the graph is initialized to contain itself only while the dominator sets of all other blocks are initialized to contain all blocks of the graph.
  • Some block can only be a dominator of another block if it is the same block or if it also dominates all the predecessors of that block. Therefore, the dominator analysis can be performed iteratively by continuely replacing a block's dominator set by the intersection of the dominator sets of all its predecessors, or else, by the block itself in case it has no predecessors.
Once the dominator analysis has been performed, all the edges whose target block dominates the source block are marked as back edges.

See Also:
AbstractEdge.isBackEdge(), AbstractEdge.setBackEdge(boolean)

checkForReducibility

private void checkForReducibility()
Checks whether this flow graph is reducible or not and sets the isReducible flag accordingly. This method relies on all the edges of this flow graph being correctly categorized as back edges or not.

See Also:
markBackEdges(), isReducible()

checkForReducibility

private void checkForReducibility(V block,
                                  java.util.BitSet path)
Recursively checks whether this flow graph is reducible or not and sets the isReducible flag accordingly. This method relies on all the edges of this flow graph being correctly categorized as back edges or not.

One of the definitions of reducibility of a directed graph is that the graph is reducible if and only if its set of forward edges contains a loop. Therefore, this method checks for the reducibility property by following the forward edges of this graph only (and simply neglecting the back edges instead of really removing them from the graph) and checking whether any loop is encountered in which case the graph is not reducible.

Parameters:
block - The vertex in the graph whose successors along forward edges are to be visited next.
path - A bitset marking the set of vertices which have already been visited along the current path. This is used to detect whether we are visiting a vertex twice along the same path in which case we would have detected a loop.
See Also:
markBackEdges(), isReducible(), AbstractVertex.getID()

isReducible

public boolean isReducible()
Returns whether this flow graph is reducible or not. The value of this flag can only be relied on after having invoked the analyze method.

Returns:
Whether this flow graph is reducible or not.
See Also:
analyze()

computeNaturalLoop

public java.util.HashSet<V> computeNaturalLoop(E backEdge)
Computes the set of vertices contained in the natural loop defined by the given backEdge. The vertices are returned in no particular order.

Parameters:
backEdge - The back edge defining the natural loop.
Returns:
The set of vertices contained in the natural loop defined by the given backEdge.

accumLoopBlocks

private void accumLoopBlocks(java.util.HashSet<V> loopBlocks,
                             V next)
Adds the given block next to the loopBlocks and, if that block was not already contained in the set of loop blocks, all its predecessors are recursively added to the set of loop blocks as well.

Parameters:
loopBlocks - The set of loop blocks being accumulated.
next - The next block to add to the loop blocks.
